member.name: T:MagicOnion.Internal.DangerousDummyNull
member.summary: Provide a dummy Null object to cheat grpc-dotnet.

remarks.para: Grpc.Net (grpc-dotnet) does not allow null values as messages. However, gRPC does not need to know the contents of the message, and MagicOnion natively handles CLR objects. so there is no problem if a null object is encountered between implementation and serialization.

grpc-dotnet also does not care about the message content, MagicOnion will replace the null value with a singleton-dummy `System.Object` instance as `T` by `Unsafe.As`. When serializing or deserializing a request/response, it will replace the dummy object back to `null` or with a dummy object.

member.code:
- Request (on server): [MagicOnion Client] | | (MessagePack binary) | [ASP.NET Core gRPC server (grpc-dotnet)] | [MessageSerializer.Deserialize<T> (MagicOnion)] | | (object or null) | [DangerousDummyNull.GetObjectOrDummyNull (MagicOnion)] | | (object or DummyNull) | [CallHandler (grpc-dotnet)] | [DangerousDummyNull.GetObjectOrDefault (MagicOnion)] | | (object or null) | [Unary method (User-code)]
- Response (on server): [Unary method (User-code)] | | (object or null) | [DangerousDummyNull.GetObjectOrDummyNull (MagicOnion)] | | (object or DummyNull) | [CallHandler (grpc-dotnet)] | [DangerousDummyNull.GetObjectOrDefault (MagicOnion)] | | (object or null) | [MessageSerializer.Serialize<T> (MagicOnion)] | | (MessagePack binary) | [ASP.NET Core gRPC server (grpc-dotnet)] | [MagicOnion Client]

remarks.para: StreamingHub message formats (from Server to Client):

item.term: Response: InvokeHubMethod (from server to client; with Exception)

remarks.para: StreamingHub message formats (from Client to Server):

item.term: ClientInvoke/Response: InvokeClientMethod (from client to server; with Exception)

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.ExperimentalAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that an API is experimental and it may change in the future.
member.remarks: This attribute allows call sites to be flagged with a diagnostic that indicates that an experimental feature is used. Authors can use this attribute to ship preview features in their assemblies.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.ExperimentalAttribute.DiagnosticId
member.summary: Gets the ID that the compiler will use when reporting a use of the API the attribute applies to.
member.remarks:
The diagnostic ID is shown in build output for warnings and errors.
This property represents the unique ID that can be used to suppress the warnings or errors, if needed.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.ExperimentalAttribute.UrlFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the URL for corresponding documentation. The API accepts a format string instead of an actual URL, creating a generic URL that includes the diagnostic ID.
member.value: The format string that represents a URL to corresponding documentation.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnscopedRefAttribute
member.summary: Used to indicate a byref escapes and is not scoped.

remarks.para: There are several cases where the C# compiler treats a as implicitly - where the compiler does not allow the to escape the method.

For example:
for instance methods.
parameters that refer to types.
parameters.
This attribute is used in those instances where the should be allowed to escape.

Applying this attribute, in any form, has impact on consumers of the applicable API. It is necessary for API authors to understand the lifetime implications of applying this attribute and how it may impact their users.

member.remarks: must refer to a static method that accepts a single parameter of type and returns an instance of the collection being built containing a copy of the data from that span. In future releases of .NET, additional patterns may be supported.

member.remarks: This should match the metadata name of the target method. For example, this might be ".ctor" if targeting the type's constructor.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsExternalInit
member.summary: Reserved to be used by the compiler for tracking metadata. This class should not be used by developers in source code.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.ModuleInitializerAttribute
member.summary: Used to indicate to the compiler that a method should be called in its containing module's initializer.
member.remarks:
When one or more valid methods with this attribute are found in a compilation, the compiler will emit a module initializer which calls each of the attributed methods.
Certain requirements are imposed on any method targeted with this attribute: - The method must be `static`. - The method must be an ordinary member method, as opposed to a property accessor, constructor, local function, etc. - The method must be parameterless. - The method must return `void`. - The method must not be generic or be contained in a generic type. - The method's effective accessibility must be `internal` or `public`.
The specification for module initializers in the .NET runtime can be found here: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/design/specs/Ecma-335-Augments.md#module-initializer

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.OverloadResolutionPriorityAttribute
member.summary: Specifies the priority of a member in overload resolution. When unspecified, the default priority is 0.

member.name: M:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.OverloadResolutionPriorityAttribute.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The priority of the attributed member. Higher numbers are prioritized, lower numbers are deprioritized. 0 is the default if no attribute is present.

member.name: P:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.OverloadResolutionPriorityAttribute.Priority
member.summary: The priority of the member.
